title: Music stops for Spotify finance chief as subscriber total soars
text:
Spotify's chief financial officer has announced he is leaving early next year as the music streaming company bemoaned a slump in its share price.

Barry McCarthy played a key role in taking Spotify public in April 2018 in an unusual "direct listing" under which it sold no new shares.

He will be replaced in January by Paul Vogel, its vice-president of financial planning and analysis, but retain a seat on the board.

The move comes after a difficult period of trading for Spotify, whose shares have fallen about a fifth in the past three months, and are 18pc lower than their debut price amid tough competition from US rivals such as Apple.

Unveiling a jump in user numbers in its third-quarter results, Spotify said its business is beating expectations. The firm added that shares are 33pc below what analysts believe they are worth.

It said: "Sometimes the stock price reflects the performance of the business and sometimes it doesn’t. But eventually, it always does."

Third quarter results were better than analysts had expected, with its premium subscriber numbers up 31pc to 113m compared with the same period last year, and revenue up 28pc to €1.73bn (£1.35bn).

The news sent shares 8pc higher in pre-market trading in New York.
